awd_titl_txt: IGE: Advancing and Strengthening Science Identity through Systematic Training (ASSIST)
awd_abstract_narration:
Developing science leaders from underrepresented minority graduate student groups such as Latinos, African Americans, and women remains a national priority. Yet the barriers to success these groups face are often not adequately addressed by traditional methods of mentoring and professionalization in science. Minority-serving institutions are uniquely poised to foster diverse science leaders, but they also require a systematic, integrated, program-wide approach geared toward nurturing and validating students' identities as scientists. This National Science Foundation Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) award to the University of Texas San Antonio cultivates science identity by integrating holistic mentoring with systematic training in science writing and public science communication. This program will test an innovative and potentially transformative model for diversifying science that engages both faculty and graduate students from the department of Environmental Science and Ecology in a community-supported, holistic, and systematic approach. The project will utilize a series of graduate courses, professional workshops, and community-based activities that seek to foster and validate underrepresented minority students' science identity. Nationally, these interventions may exist informally, but they are rarely, if ever, fully integrated into a coherent graduate STEM program. Developing diverse leaders in science professions is crucial as scientists navigate interdisciplinary knowledge demands and cultural challenges in a globalized and media-saturated world. 

The goal of this IGE project is to cultivate a science identity for underrepresented minority graduate students through the acquisition of a knowledge base (competence), the ability to perform science practices (performance), and the acknowledgement by significant others in the field (recognition). The researchers propose that fostering these identity components and making them visible in scientific disciplines and public communities can be achieved through three interrelated interventions: holistic mentoring, writing-to-learn science, and public science communication. Holistic mentoring, both in and outside the classroom environment will provide the underlying framework necessary to address the needs and challenges faced by underrepresented minority students. In addition, this project hypothesizes that holistic mentoring transforms the challenges of systematic training in research-based science writing and public science communication into opportunities to validate students' scientific competence and leadership skills. The project will use a mixed-methods assessment approach to analyze not only each intervention but also on the relationships among all three interventions. Therefore, it seeks to provide an evidence-based validation of the impact of holistic mentoring and systematic communications training on cultivating a scientific ethos for underrepresented minority graduate students. 

The Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) program is focused on research in graduate education.  The goals of IGE are to pilot, test and validate innovative approaches to graduate education and to generate the knowledge required to move these approaches into the broader community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF-funded project aimed to enhance science identity among environmental science graduate students through a comprehensive approach involving holistic mentoring, improved science communication and writing pedagogy, and focused training to increase comprehension of ecological and environmental science topics. Our goal was to give students the tools and support they need to grow as confident, effective scientists who can communicate complex ideas to diverse audiences and become leaders in their chosen fields.

The project contributed significant advancements in understanding how science identity develops among graduate students in environmental science, with particular attention to those from historically underrepresented backgrounds. Intellectual merit outcomes include:

  • Development of Holistic Mentoring Practices: We designed and implemented a mentoring framework that combined academic support, professional development, and social-emotional guidance. This approach was particularly successful in helping students see themselves as scientists by aligning mentorship with their individual needs and career goals.
  • Science Communication and Writing Pedagogy: We developed a curriculum focused on enhancing science communication skills, specifically tailored to environmental science topics. Through workshops, assignments, and feedback loops, students substantially improved their ability to write and speak about scientific concepts for academic and public audiences.
  • Enhanced Understanding of Ecological and Environmental Science Concepts: We observed students with greater confidence and increased ability to communicate their understanding of environmental science topics. Course content emphasized complex issues such as climate change, ecosystem management, and biodiversity conservation, allowing students to build a solid knowledge base that informed their research and public communication efforts.

The project's approach was grounded in evidence-based instructional methods and continuous assessment, which allowed us to refine and validate our mentoring and teaching strategies. Workshops and mentoring related to attending scientific conferences also aided in removing barriers between practicing scientists and students working to become scientists. Additionally, our findings contribute to the growing body of literature on the development of science identity and the role of mentorship in shaping future scientists.

This project had a far-reaching impact beyond the immediate student population involved, extending its influence to the broader scientific community, the general public, and underserved communities' understanding of the environment.

  • Strengthened Science Identity in Diverse Graduate Students: The holistic mentoring model significantly increased self-identification as scientists among participating students, with the greatest impact observed among first-generation college students and those from underrepresented groups. The project has produced a replicable mentoring model that can be adopted by other programs seeking to cultivate science identity in diverse student populations.
  • Improvement in Public Science Communication: The project enabled graduate students to translate their specialized knowledge into accessible language, thus bridging the gap between academic research and public understanding. Students developed communication materials, including blogs, articles, and presentations, disseminated to local communities and online platforms, engaging the public in environmental science topics.
  • Capacity Building for Future Environmental Leaders: Students who participated in the program reported greater confidence in their scientific skills and expressed a heightened commitment to environmental advocacy and science outreach. Many graduates have taken positions in academic, nonprofit, and governmental roles where they continue to leverage their communication and mentoring skills to further environmental causes.
  • Building Partnerships: This project laid the foundation for building partnerships between several minority-serving institutions and several federal agencies. Seven minority-serving institutions (UTSA, New Mexico State University, Fort Valley State University, Tuskegee University, Alabama A & M, Bethune-Cookman University, and Bowe State University) have formed a consortium and signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the US Fish and Wildlife Service. We are sharing the lessons we learned from the NSF Project with these schools and agencies to improve the retention and success of graduate students in the fields of natural resources and conservation. From what we have learned from this NSF Project, we have completed a pilot internship program with the Environmental Protection Agency, leading to several graduate students working for the Agency. We are now discussing expanding this pilot to our consortium partners listed above.

This project provided invaluable insights into the development of science identity through mentoring and pedagogy designed to strengthen communication skills and comprehension of environmental science. By holistically supporting graduate students, we have prepared them for successful careers and empowered them to engage in meaningful, effective science communication. The resources and knowledge developed have been the foundation for new initiatives to foster diversity and inclusion in the environmental sciences and beyond.

The success of this project demonstrates the potential for broader adoption of these methods across STEM disciplines and serves as a model for how NSF-funded programs can impact the next generation of scientists and the communities they serve.
